content.title: Celiac Disease
content.summary: Immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by gluten ingestion in genetically susceptible individuals, causing small intestinal villous atrophy and malabsorption
key_points: Autoimmune enteropathy triggered by gluten (wheat, barley, rye)
Strong HLA association (HLA-DQ2 in 90%, DQ8 in 10%)
tTG-IgA is screening test of choice; EMA highly specific
Small bowel biopsy shows villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, intraepithelial lymphocytes
Gluten-free diet is only treatment - lifelong adherence required
Dermatitis herpetiformis is skin manifestation of celiac
Complications: refractory sprue, EATL, osteoporosis, infertility

statement.text: Celiac disease is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by gluten in genetically susceptible individuals (HLA-DQ2/DQ8). Gluten peptides trigger T-cell mediated inflammation causing villous atrophy and malabsorption. Diagnosis requires serology (tTG-IgA) and small bowel biopsy while on gluten-containing diet. Treatment is strict lifelong gluten-free diet.
statement.formal: Celiac = Gluten exposure + Genetic susceptibility (HLA-DQ2/8) + Villous atrophy + Positive serology

explanation.intuition: Gluten proteins from wheat, barley, and rye cross the intestinal barrier and are modified by tissue transglutaminase (tTG). In people with specific HLA types, the immune system recognizes these modified proteins as foreign, triggering inflammation that destroys the tiny finger-like projections (villi) that absorb nutrients. No villi = malabsorption of everything.
explanation.key_insight: Must test ON a gluten-containing diet - gluten-free diet before testing causes false negatives. IgA deficiency is more common in celiac and causes false-negative IgA-based tests - check total IgA or use IgG-based tests. Villous atrophy is not specific to celiac - consider other causes if no response to GFD.
explanation.technical_details: Marsh classification grades histology: Type 0 normal, Type 1 increased IELs, Type 2 + crypt hyperplasia, Type 3a partial villous atrophy, 3b subtotal, 3c total. Response to GFD confirms diagnosis. Non-responsive celiac requires reassessment of diagnosis, dietary compliance, and exclusion of refractory sprue.

definitions_glossary.celiac_disease: Immune-mediated enteropathy from gluten ingestion in genetically susceptible individuals
definitions_glossary.gluten: Storage proteins in wheat (gliadin), barley (hordein), rye (secalin)
definitions_glossary.villous_atrophy: Loss of small intestinal villi causing malabsorption
definitions_glossary.ttg_iga: Tissue transglutaminase IgA antibody - primary screening test
definitions_glossary.endomysial_antibody: EMA - highly specific antibody for celiac (>99%)
definitions_glossary.hla_dq2_dq8: HLA types required for celiac development; absence excludes disease
definitions_glossary.dermatitis_herpetiformis: Intensely pruritic vesicular rash - skin manifestation of celiac
definitions_glossary.marsh_classification: Histological grading system for celiac enteropathy
definitions_glossary.refractory_sprue: Celiac not responding to GFD; may progress to EATL
definitions_glossary.gluten_free_diet: Avoidance of wheat, barley, rye - only treatment for celiac
definitions_glossary.intraepithelial_lymphocytes: Increased T-cells in intestinal epithelium - early finding

pathophysiology.mechanism: Gluten peptides resist complete digestion and cross epithelial barrier. tTG deamidates gliadin, creating epitopes recognized by HLA-DQ2/8. CD4+ T-cells drive inflammation; cytokines damage enterocytes; intraepithelial CD8+ lymphocytes cause direct injury. Villous atrophy results in malabsorption.

serology.dgp: Deamidated gliadin peptide - useful if IgA deficient

diagnostic_criteria.biopsy: Villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, increased IELs (>25/100 enterocytes)

gluten_free_diet.requirement: Strict lifelong avoidance of wheat, barley, rye
gluten_free_diet.response: Clinical improvement weeks; histological healing months-years
gluten_free_diet.monitoring: Serology (tTG-IgA should normalize), symptoms, nutritional status

treatment_options.nutritional_support: Iron, folate, B12, calcium, vitamin D supplementation as needed

definition.@value: Immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by gluten causing villous atrophy and malabsorption

learning_objectives: Recognize classic and atypical presentations of celiac
Order appropriate serologic tests and interpret results
Explain the role of biopsy and GFD in diagnosis
clinical_pearls: Must test ON gluten-containing diet - GFD causes false negatives
IgA deficiency common in celiac - check total IgA
Dermatitis herpetiformis = celiac until proven otherwise
Non-response to GFD = reassess diagnosis, compliance, or refractory sprue
common_misconceptions: Any gluten sensitivity is celiac (false - NCGS is different)
Biopsy not needed if serology positive (false - biopsy still recommended in adults)
Oats are always forbidden (false - pure oats often tolerated)
